div1.p: Carter asserts that Reed laid the foundation for work on yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William Cabell Bruce, [n.d.]

Keep: Re Biographic sketches
in History of the U. of Va. by
Wm Cabell Bruce
Dear Mr. Bruce:
div1.p:
Both of your notes received, and I have put off answering you until
Sunday as I am too busy during the week.

1/ I am willing to admit--or indeed assert--that I, myself: LePrince
and others did all we could----and on the whole good work--in the assistance
of Gorgas in the sanitation of the Isthmus. It was primarily his job.
however.

2/ You have, I think, misunderstood this part of my note. Unques-
tionably, your work in Panama--and indeed all fwork for the elimination
of yellow fever since--has been based on Reed's discovery. We received
from him not a “cue” but a foundation for work. What I said was that
my research work “had determined the direction” of Reed's--gave him his
cue so to speak.

Few scientific discoveries--medical or otherwise--are in their en-
tirety the work of any one man: He who puts the capstone on the com-
pleted structure gets--as he should--the credit for it, but the founda-
tion and walls may--and generally have been--built by many hands.

Reed, for instance, had the knowledge of the discovery by Ross of the
conveyance of malaria from man, to man by the Anopheles mosquito: Of Big-
nami's demonstration that a period of 8 to 10 days was required for the
developement of the malaria parasite in this mosquito--prior to the end of which
admitted.”

Does this make the matter plain? I certainly have not meant to
imply that Reed's discovery was not the basis of the yellow fever work
in Panama. It unquestionably was.
